intro: Lupinus albopilosus, commonly known as the white-hairy lupine, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its tall, erect stems and clusters of small, white or pale pink flowers. The plant has soft, hairy leaves that are typically gray-green in color, and it produces cylindrical pods that contain several seeds. Lupinus albopilosus is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and has the ability to fix nitrogen in the soil through its root nodules. It thrives in dry, rocky habitats and is often found in open woodlands and grasslands.
